Graphical abstract A review of lignin sources, methods for preparing carbon quantum dots using lignin as a carbon source, their key properties, and applications in energy and photocatalysis. Carbon quantum dots are a new type of fluorescent nanomaterials with broad applications in drug delivery, bioimaging, solar cells, and photocatalysis due to their unique biocompatibility, optical properties and easy functionalization. In the meantime, because of its high carbon content, renewable nature, and environmental friendliness, lignin has drawn the attention of researchers as a desirable raw material for creating carbon quantum dots. Here we review the synthesis of carbon quantum dots from lignin, focusing on synthetic methods, properties, and applications in energy, and photocatalysis. Later, we propose some new development prospects from preparation methods, luminescence mechanism research, application, and commercial cost of lignin carbon quantum dots. Finally, based on this, the development prospects of this field are prospected and summarized. Keywords Lignin Carbon quantum dots Optical Energy Photocatalysis 1 Introduction Lignin is known as one of the fundamental lignocellulosic components due to its unique characteristics [1–3]. This complex three-dimensional amorphous polymer comprises non-carbohydrate polyphenolic substances, phenylpropane, and methoxy. The polymer consists of three fundamental structures, namely, S (butyl), G (guaiacyl), and H (p-hydroxyphenyl), with 0–2 OCH3 moiety on the aromatic ring. These structures can be represented in alcohols, such as coumaryl alcohol, pinacol, and mostly alcohol, which are linked together with 5–5, 4–O–5, β–β, β–5, β–O–4, α–O–4, β–1 bonds [4]. Lignin composition varies significantly across plant species and is characterized by irregular connections between constituent units. These units come together in diverse ways and give rise to the complex amorphous structure of lignin. Generally, lignin functions as an adhesive agent by occupying the gaps within hemicellulose and cellulose with polymers. Plant cell walls, especially lignified plants, contain abundant lignin, including woody and herbaceous plants and all vascular plants. The major function of lignin is to enhance the strength of plant tissues and to impart hardness and stability to wood and other plant tissues. Softwood lignin content is approximately 24%–33% with G units dominating. Hardwood typically contains 18%–25% lignin with most G and S units and fewer H units. In contrast, grasses have a 15%–25% lignin content, with more H units (approximately 5%–35%) than hardwoods and softwoods [5–7]. It has been observed that apart from lignin obtained from natural plant sources such as trees, certain industrial and agricultural wastes also carry lignin [8]. Lignin, a major industrial and agricultural waste component, produces more than 5 billion metric tons annually. The paper industry alone accounts for 600,000 metric tons of lignin waste annually [9]. Lignin can be found in the wastes and effluents yielded from the pulp and paper factory. The waste generated from the pulp industry, including waste liquors from wood pulping and waste from wood processing operations such as sawdust, wood chips, and bark, may also contain considerable amounts of lignin [10]. The agri-food industry generates significant quantities of high-quality lignin-containing waste comprising fruit peels, seeds, shells, bagasse, leaves, straw, pomace, and cuttings [11], which can be used in chemical synthesis, energy production, and others through specialized treatment and separation methods (Fig. 1 ) [12]. Cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin are important natural lignocellulosic polymers [13,14]. Like other bio-renewable polymers, lignin offers numerous advantages such as bio-renewability, low cost, high carbon content, and availability in abundant quantities as an industrial waste [15]. Lignin is also a natural aspartic acid derivative comprising multiple aromatic rings and hydroxyl groups in its structure. Lignin possesses high-temperature resistance, acid resistance and oxidation resistance. However, lignin is susceptible to enzymatic reactions under alkaline conditions, which produce various oligomers and monomers [16]. Additionally, it possesses robust antioxidant features that can effectively prevent free radicals and oxidative reactions [17]. Due to its high weather resistance and stability, lignin is extensively employed in wood preservatives, pigments, plastics, paints [18], inks and other industrial fields. As such, it plays a critical role in enhancing product quality and prolonging lifespan [19]. Furthermore, lignin is a valuable precursor for producing flavours, cosmetics [20], and pharmaceuticals [21]. Lignin has emerged as a versatile material with numerous applications across various industries, such as biofuels [22,23], construction materials [24], antimicrobials, and biomedicine. Lignin is rich in phenolic hydroxyl groups that exhibit excellent antimicrobial, antioxidant, and ultraviolet-resistant characteristics, ideal for use as active sites that can be modified to enhance their biological activities. Moreover, studies have shown that lignin can also increase the service life of food products and uphold food safety. Furthermore, lignin can be utilized in advancing drug carriers and hydrogels [15,25], adhesives, cement, resins and binders [26], as well as in the production of antimicrobial and antioxidant agents. Furthermore, lignin contains polyphenols with antioxidant, bactericidal, and antifungal properties, making it an effective defense against pests and diseases. As a result, lignin and its derivatives are increasingly used as natural products and chemical analogs for crop protection, and the need for harmful pesticides is reduced [6]. A newly developed hybridized organic–inorganic copper-containing material, known as lignin@Cu, has been successfully obtained by combining lignin with copper (II) ions. According to preliminary tests conducted on crops in greenhouses, it has been observed that lignin@Cu has greater efficacy than commercially available copper hydroxide-based pesticides against phytophthora on tomato plants, indicating that these materials hold great potential as plant protectants [27]. In the biomedical sector, lignin-derived products are gaining attention from researchers. The investigation is currently concentrated on creating intelligent bio-based nanocarriers, which physically attach or encapsulate active biological agents. Notably, lignin nanoparticles exhibit significant promise in medical therapeutic and diagnostic applications. Lignin nanotubes and lignin hydrogels are significant tissue engineering and DNA synthesis components. Furthermore, lignosulfonates can be utilized in drug development to promote immune system activation by limiting oxidative activity [25]. Lignin-based hydrogels are also a viable option for drug transport systems [15]. In short, lignin shows broad biological activities such as anti-tumour and anti-viral properties, making it a valuable component of medical therapy. As a natural polymer sunscreen, lignin is also helpful in safeguarding human skin from ultraviolet radiation [6]. Lithium-ion batteries are touted as the promising yet encouraging energy storage technology for modern electric or hybrid cars and portable electronics. Silicon, an ideal anode material, is receiving extensive attention for its application in next-generation lithium-ion batteries. Recently, it has been established that lignin-derived binders can be widely used for silicon anodes [28]. There is growing interest in replacing petroleum-derived materials with renewable lignin-based materials and cellulose derivatives to achieve sustainable and eco-friendly energy storage systems. This approach provides a viable pathway for developing green lithium battery materials [29]. A recent study yielded a high-performance silicon nanoparticle anode. This silicon-based composite electrode has low impedance values, significantly enhancing its electrochemical performance. Based on the characterization results, the silicon-lignin composite electrode was found suitable as a replacement for the conventional binder. The Si nanoparticles were evenly dispersed and enclosed in cross-linked lignin before the heat treatment. This cross-linked lignin also created a three-dimensional structure around the Si nanoparticles [26]. This composite electrode has been observed to demonstrate excellent electrochemical performance, thereby highlighting its potential as a promising candidate for electrochemical applications. The high carbon content of lignin (one-step preparation of lignosulfonate acid-derived carbonaceous solid acids) and easily modified aromatic rings provide structural possibilities and abundant active sites for its use as a catalyst precursor. The resulting lignin-based catalyst shows remarkable performance in processes such as proton transfer or electrochemistry in fuel cells, catalyzing multicomponent reactions, hydrolysis, and dehydration of biomass such as converting xylose to furfural in ionic liquids [11]. Lignin is also a promising feedstock for biofuels and biochemical production by biorefineries, owing to its abundant carbon content. It has been noted that lignin is burnt to provide energy for biomass conversion in most large-scale industrial operations employing plant polysaccharides [30]. Carbon quantum dots represent a significant class of fluorescent carbon-based nanomaterials. Typically, these dots are characterized as small and spherical particles that are uniformly distributed, and possess particle size generally not exceeding 10 nm. Along with the tunable emission wavelength and high quantum yield that traditional semiconductor quantum dots possess, carbon quantum dots exhibit several other remarkable properties such as high chemical inertness, ease of surface modification, good biocompatibility, low cytotoxicity, and excellent photostability. These properties have hooked the interest of the academician in recent years, particularly in photocatalysis, fluorescence sensing, drug delivery, in vivo imaging, cell imaging, and energy conversion and storage. When preparing carbon quantum dots (CQDs), the choice of raw materials has an important impact on the properties (e.g., optical, electrical, catalytic properties, etc.) of the final carbon quantum dots. Conventional heavy metal quantum dots are toxic, so it is particularly important to produce high-quality carbon quantum dots in a green and economical way. Biomass, as a renewable resource characterized by wide sources, large reserves and environmental friendliness [31], is ideal for the preparation of carbon quantum dots. So far, various types of biomass have been used as carbon sources to prepare carbon quantum dots including grapefruit peels [24], orange peels [32], lemon juice [33], tea waste [34], roses [35], kelp [36], grape skins [37], Aloe vera [38], and crab shell [39], etc., but the synthesis process is relatively cumbersome and the quantum yields are very low, which greatly limits the carbon quantum dots applications [40]. Therefore, based on green chemistry and economics considerations, research is needed to explore carbon quantum dots with high fluorescence properties. Among them, lignin, which is recycled and renewable in nature, can be used as the initial carbon source to prepare lignin-based carbon quantum dots. Lignin is a rich source and is not only the second largest green renewable resource in nature, slightly behind cellulose in content. Moreover, lignin has a large recycling potential as part of industrial waste (e.g., by-products from pulp and cellulose production processes). Converting lignin into carbon quantum dots not only helps to reduce the environmental burden of lignin waste, but also provides a viable pathway for high-value utilization of the waste. With a natural aromatic structure, high carbon content, non-toxic and harmless. Because lignin is rich in aromatic structures and oxygen-containing functional groups, carbon quantum dots prepared from lignin as a carbon source usually exhibit excellent optical properties, especially strong fluorescence emission under UV excitation, as well as strong fluorescence stability and high quantum yield. Lignin-based carbon quantum dots not only can effectively reduce the raw material cost of the carbon quantum dot preparation process and realize the high-value utilization of waste resources, but also usually have excellent biocompatibility and stable fluorescence emission. Meanwhile, lignin, compared with other biomass-based such as cellulose, has a high carbon content and a large number of natural aromatic structures, which theoretically makes it easier to obtain carbon quantum dots [41]. Therefore, the large-scale preparation of lignin-based carbon quantum dots (L-CQDs) using lignin as a precursor not only turns waste into treasure, but also promotes sustainable economic development. Lignin utilization as a high-quality precursor for carbon quantum dots synthesis has been reported in previous studies, resulting in the development of nanoscale fluorescent materials with exceptional properties [42]. For example, 12-h continuous heating at 180 °C prepared blue fluorescent quantum dots via a hydrothermal approach and applied to cellular imaging [43]. Using pyrolysis, Chen et al. successfully prepared a 23.4% blue fluorescent quantum dots yield. In addition to hydrothermal and pyrolysis methods, microwave and solvothermal approaches have also been applied to prepare carbon quantum dots [44]. In summary, lignin, as a crucial natural raw material, shows immense potential as a precursor for carbon quantum dots. This review paper highlights the current findings on the synthesis and function of carbon quantum dots obtained from lignin in the energy and photocatalysis sectors. 2 Preparation of L-CQDs Multiple techniques have recently been assessed for creating carbon quantum dots, focusing on various advanced functionalities, compositions, and structures that are cost-effective and scalable for large-scale production while ensuring size control. Each preparation method has its benefits and drawbacks; therefore, it is crucial to opt for a suitable method based on the specific requirements. Carbon quantum dots properties and applications can be modified by adjusting reaction conditions and introducing doping agents. Lignin is a complex reticulated biomacromolecule recognized as the second-largest green and clean energy source in nature due to its high carbon content. It possesses natural advantages over organic small molecules, such as thick cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, and serves as an ideal precursor for carbon quantum dots. The lignin-based carbon quantum dots (L-CQDs) have found extensive applications in ion detection, luminescent materials, bioimaging, photocatalysis, and other domains. Numerous techniques have been explored for preparing L-CQDs to achieve simple, fast, size-controllable, and commercial production of high-quality L-CQDs. The most common strategies for synthesizing L-CQDs using lignin include hydrothermal, microwave, and pyrolytic carbonization. The process of synthesizing carbon quantum dots is depicted in Fig. 2 . 2.1 Hydrothermal method Hydrothermal methods are environmentally friendly and cost-effective for producing quantum dots using high pressure and temperature under aqueous conditions. While the method is non-toxic, controllable, and simple, it often lacks control over particle size and may contain impurities in the resulting product. Xue et al. showed that L-CQDs prepared via this method are almost spherical with a diameter of not exceeding 10 nm and exhibit high water solubility, low cytotoxicity, excellent photoluminescence, and good biocompatibility [43]. Furthermore, Zhang et al. demonstrated that multifunctional L-CQDs co-doped with nitrogen lanthanum can be produced via a single-step hydrothermal approach with enzymatically degraded lignin as a precursor. The carbon quantum dots obtained possess a diameter of approximately 2.2 nm, blue luminescence, and high stability. They are also highly water-soluble, exhibit cell membrane permeability with minimal cytotoxicity, and can be employed to identify ClO−, Sn2+, and Fe3+ ions in cells [57]. A dual-step approach was introduced to address the poor fluorescence characteristics of L-CQDs prepared through traditional hydrothermal methods. The ethanol supercritical/precious metal catalyst was employed to cleave lignin, which yielded four different cleaved lignin under varying cleavage conditions. Subsequently, these cleaved lignin fragments served as carbon precursors for producing L-CQDs without needing additional reagents. Fig. 3 b illustrates the formation mechanism. The L-CQDs synthesized from cleaved lignin exhibit a high concentration of low-molecular-weight compounds, resulting in superior photoluminescence properties compared to OL-CQDs synthesized using the ordinary one-pot hydrothermal approach. Fig. 4 a, b depict the four L-CQDs and OL-CQDs in sunlight and 365 nm of ultraviolet irradiation. When exposed to sunlight, the OL-CQDs produced from uncracked lignin appeared brown, while the four L-CQDs were transparent or light yellow. The four L-CQDs showed blue-green or bright blue fluorescence, with the L-CQDs having the brightness intensity, whereas the OL-CQDs showed mild green fluorescence when exposed to 365 nm of ultraviolet light. After a month at the usual temperature, the fluorescence of the L-CQDs-1 solution prevailed steady, with just a 5% drop in intensity. The absorption spectra of all L-CQDs are presented in Fig. 4c, revealing a light absorption range within 200–400 nm. The spectra exhibited a buffer region of approximately 230 nm and a significant absorption peak at approximately 280 nm can be attributed to the transition of n-n* in the aromatic ring. These findings suggest that all L-CQDs were present in π-π*, n-π*, and n-n* transitions. The results indicate that preparing L-CQDs with cleaved lignin is more effective for improving their fluorescence performance than the conventional hydrothermal method that employs virgin lignin [48]. Moreover, the resulting FA@L-CQDs exhibited the potential to pinpoint and mark tumour cells after the subsequent combining and bursting of L-CQDs with folic acid (FA). Black liquor is a problematic source of pollution yet with potential application value that is generated in the pulp factory. L-CQDs were successfully developed by employing a 12-h one-pot hydrothermal heating at 180 °C using lignin extracted from black liquor. The fluorescence intensities of carbon quantum dots were detected between 89.09 and 183.66, while aminated NL-CQDs and hydroxylated RL-CQDs showed higher fluorescence intensities of 605.3 and 689.22, respectively (Fig. 4d). Notably, the fluorescence intensity only decreased by 5% after three months of storage at room temperature, thus indicating its potential for cellular imaging [42]. The hydrothermal approach produces carbon quantum dots with non-uniform size distribution, impeding their applicability. Additionally, the preparation conditions of the hydrothermal method significantly affect its nature and yield, which necessitates certain optimization and adjustment of the preparation conditions to obtain the desired carbon quantum dots. For other biomass resources, the quantum yield of L-CQDs is relatively low, so improving their quantum yield remains a challenge. Despite its limitations, the hydrothermal method remains one of the most straightforward, cost-effective, and easy-to-implement preparation methods for carbon quantum dots. Table 1 illustrates the carbon quantum dots obtained from various biomass wastes using this method, highlighting its wide usage and high efficiency. Furthermore, researchers have employed multiple methods to treat precursors or aminate the carbon quantum dots produced via hydrothermal to yield products with superior properties. The synthesis of carbon quantum dots using lignin as the carbon source via the hydrothermal method holds great potential. However, the structural complexity of lignin can lead to the formation of by-products during synthesis, which may affect the purity and stability of the products. To further improve the quality and performance of lignin-derived carbon quantum dots, it is essential to optimize the reaction conditions and carefully regulate factors such as temperature, pressure, and reaction time. Precisely controlling the morphology and properties of the carbon quantum dots through these adjustments remains a significant challenge. 2.2 Pyrolysis Pyrolysis is a thermochemical reaction from 350 to 750 °C to carbonize organic materials. This process is a green and facile approach to yield carbon quantum dots under inert atmospheric conditions like nitrogen. Pyrolysis provides exact tuning of the size, shape, and surface characteristics of carbon quantum dots by regulating process temperature, time, and environment. Carbon quantum dots with specific fluorescence characteristics were yielded by utilising lignin and solvent-free pyrolysis at varying temperatures. At 350 °C, the resulting carbon quantum dots showed uniform dispersion and bright blue fluorescence. Due to the high oxygen content on the carbon quantum dots surface, they have a high affinity for Fe3+ coordination with excellent sensitivity, making them a potential fluorescent Fe3+ sensor [44]. A novel aminated lignin was successfully prepared through the Mannich reaction, followed by pyrolysis at 300 °C to yield carbon quantum dots with approximately 4 nm. The amination of the lignin skeleton with primary amine groups resulted in the formation of aminated lignin carbon quantum dots (AL-CQDs), which exhibited remarkable pH stability, sensitivity, and fluorescence activity. The study also explored the pH effect on AL-CQD fluorescence intensity. The results showed that AL-CQDs exhibit excellent stability over a wide pH range of 1–13. The fluorescence intensity of AL-CQDs was gradually enhanced as the pH increased from 1 to 7, reaching its maximum at pH = 7, while it reduced substantially from pH 7 to 13. The biocompatibility of AL-CQDs was also found to be superior in cellular imaging, demonstrating an effective and facile strategy for biomedical and cellular imaging applications. Overall, the study suggests that the AL-CQDs could be an encouraging candidate for cellular imaging and biomedical function because of their excellent stability and biocompatibility [47]. The creation of carbon quantum dots through pyrolysis poses significant challenges, primarily due to the high process conditions that require careful control to maintain product quality. The pyrolysis process may also yield harmful or unnecessary by-products, leading to environmental pollution. Furthermore, carbon quantum dot production via pyrolysis necessitates higher temperatures and greater energy consumption. Hence, research into preparing carbon quantum dots from lignin via pyrolysis remains challenging. The aromatic and side-chain structures of lignin macromolecules make them susceptible to forming char or macromolecule polymers during pyrolysis rather than carbon quantum dots. Consequently, further research requires further research to control the temperature and reaction conditions to achieve carbon quantum dots with the desired properties and fewer impurities. In conclusion, pyrolysis can efficiently convert lignin into carbon quantum dots with high yield, but it requires precise control of temperature and reaction time, and too high or too low temperature may affect the morphology and properties of carbon quantum dots. Therefore, in the future, we can focus on the optimization of reaction parameters to further amplify the advantages of pyrolysis for the preparation of carbon quantum dots. 2.3 Microwave heating Microwave heating is a highly efficient method suitable for generating small molecules. This method has the added advantage of not requiring acid catalysts and allowing water to serve as a reaction medium. Using conventional microwave-assisted carbonization techniques, carbon quantum dots with exceptional water solubility can be produced quickly, affordably, and in an environmentally friendly manner. This method is highly scalable, and its performance hinges on the option of carbon source and whether or not acid catalysis is employed. However, one limitation of this method is the inability to regulate the size of carbon quantum dots [31]. Rodríguez-Padrón et al. synthesized carbon quantum dots using lignocellulosic residues derived from the paper and pulp industry as a carbon source. The synthesis process involved a catalytic microwave-assisted reaction via a solid acid catalyst. This study has demonstrated that the prepared quantum dots show remarkable photostability properties, which can lead to further conversions of waste into carbon quantum dots with superior fluorescence behaviour. However, it is noteworthy that the fluorescence quantum yield produced in this study was only 2.7%. Therefore, numerous challenges still exist to be overcome in expanding the scale of production and enhancing the efficiency of the synthesis method [45]. Si et al. demonstrated a rapid and efficient one-pot synthesis strategy for adapting nitrogen-doped carbon quantum dots using an acid-catalyzed ethanol–water cosolvent system and microwave heating. This method utilized natural lignin to produce quantum dots with a bright violet photoluminescence property within only 10 min (Fig. 5 c). The synthesized quantum dots displayed uniformity, small nanoparticle sizes, and a mean particle size of 2.6 nm (Fig. 5d). The exceptional ability of up-conversion fluorescence can be attributed to nitrogen doping. This process effectively amplifies carbon quantum dot emission by facilitating the upward movement of electrons in the Fermi energy levels and conduction bands. The unique property of up-conversion fluorescence holds immense potential in biological imaging and can be leveraged to obtain better insights into biological systems [46]. However, the lack of reporting on production yields in this study hinders the possibility of evaluating the scalability and methodological efficiency of the approach. Microwave heating is a commonly employed method for synthesizing carbon quantum dots because of its equipment simplicity, ease of operation, and high efficiency. However, when using lignin as the carbon source, the complex structure of lignin poses challenges for carbon quantum dot formation. Lignin molecules contain many aromatic and side-chain structures, which are not conducive to carbon quantum dots, leading to lower quantum yields. To overcome this challenge, it is necessary to select suitable acid catalysis to obtain carbon quantum dots with superior performance and higher quantum yields. The selection of appropriate acid catalysis is crucial in preparing L-CQDs, and further research is required to optimize the process. 2.4 Solvothermal Solvothermal methods have emerged as a popular option to synthesize carbon quantum dots. In this method, an autoclave made of stainless steel with a Teflon liner combines an inorganic or organic carbon source with one or more solvents. The raw carbon source is then heated continuously for a certain time and transformed into carbon quantum dots under high pressure and temperature in air or N2 atmosphere. The primary advantages of this approach are its eco-friendliness, affordability, ease of operation, and minimal equipment requirements. However, the low quantum yield of lignin-derived carbon quantum dots has been a significant drawback researchers have sought to address. To this end, Pang et al. synthesized nitrogen-doped carbon quantum dots (N-CQDs) through controlled pyrolysis of alkali lignin in isopropanol, ethanol, and deionized water using diethylenetriamine as a nitrogen dopant. Alkali lignin retrieved from the paper/pulp factory contains hydrophilic hydroxyl groups on its side chains and a hydrophobic aromatic backbone, which can merge to yield primordial clusters in solvents (Fig. 5a). When exposed to increased temperature, the fundamental clusters undergo a transformation process, leading to the formation of primary aromatic clusters that are created through a series of dehydration, polymerization, and condensation reactions. These reactions take place mainly in the aliphatic portion among various lignin molecules. At the same time, DETA molecules are incorporated into the main aromatic clusters through addition reactions, resulting in nitrogen doping. Over time, the primary aromatic clusters are transformed into the final N-CQDs through aromatization and carbonation. Among them, the N-CQDs prepared using ethanol (N-CQDs-et) display distinctive structures, featuring numerous surface functional moieties, uniform size of prepared quantum dots, and particle size around 5 nm. Due to their fluorescence stability, long fluorescence lifetime, and good biocompatibility, N-CQDs are highly sought for their potential applicability in various functions, including cell imaging and metal ion detection. The doping of a significant number of nitrogen atoms in these quantum dots has not only led to a marked improvement in their yield. Still, it has also resulted in excellent sensitivity and selectivity towards Co2+ and Fe3+ ions. Using lignin materials in conjunction with ethanol is an optimal green route for the commercial production of N-CQDs, possibly owing to their ease of recycling and low toxicity [67]. Noticeably, the solvothermal approach is more effective than traditional hydrothermal methods regarding quantum yield. Jiang et al. successfully created nitrogen-doped lignin carbon quantum dots (N-L-CQDs) by using an alkali lignin carbon source and a deep eutectic solvent as the nitrogen source. The quantum yield of the N-L-CQDs was 7.95% and exhibited exceptional selectivity and sensitivity towards Fe3+ with a detection threshold of 0.44 µM. The N-L-CQDs synthesized as fluorescent sensors give a straightforward, cost-effective, and accurate method for detecting metal ions in biology and the environment, which could be highly valuable in environmental monitoring and biomedical analysis [68]. Solvothermal methods have emerged as a promising pathway for synthesizing carbon quantum dots. This approach is characterized by its eco-friendliness, cost-effectiveness, and simplicity. Innovative methodologies utilizing alkali lignin and various solvents, such as ethanol and deep eutectic solvents, have substantially augmented quantum dot production. Moreover, these methods have improved their selectivity and sensitivity to specific metal ions such as Co2+ and Fe3+. The advancements highlight the possibility of L-CQDs in biomedical analysis and environmental monitoring. This is due to their exceptional fluorescence stability, biocompatibility, and impressive detection capabilities. The use of green routes, such as the solvothermal method, combined with nitrogen doping, presents a promising strategy for the large-scale production of highly functional carbon quantum dots. 3 Structural characteristics of carbon quantum dots obtained from lignin Carbon quantum dots are nanocrystals composed of a small number of nanocluster molecules or atoms [69]. These structures are generally amorphous and crystalline with surface functional groups. Numerous studies have indicated that sp2 carbon segments on carbon quantum dots typically suffer from poor crystallinity defects, which are more prevalent than graphene quantum dots. The latter contains graphene lattices within the dots, similar to monolayer or multilayer graphene crystal structures. The study conducted by Wang et al. presents an analysis of the structural properties of nitrogen-doped carbon quantum dots (NCQDs) that were synthesized from alkali lignin as a carbon source. The NCQDs were found to be spherical, with a consistent size distribution ranging between 1.3 and 3.2 nm. The lattice stripes were well-defined, with a lattice spacing of approximately 0.21 nm. The XRD spectra indicated two diffraction peaks at 20.66° (d 002 = 0.34 nm) and 42.65° (d 100 = 0.21 nm), which affirmed the existence of abundant moieties and carbon atoms in the graphite nucleus. These findings suggest that the NCQDs comprise an amorphous carbon phase and graphite sp2 carbon clusters [70]. A recent study found that nitrogen-doped NCQDs produced from sulfated lignin exhibited a d-spacing of 0.392 nm. The structural characteristics of these samples were analyzed using Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 6 a), which revealed that the peaks at 1350 cm−1 (D-band) and 1581 cm−1 (G-band) corresponded to disordered sp3 hybridized carbon atoms and vibrations of ordered sp2 hybridized carbon atoms [49]. In a separate study, hydrothermal method produced SCQDs with a mean diameter of (5.91 ± 0.032) nm in sulfuric acid solution. The crystal structure observed in high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images displayed a lattice spacing of 0.24 nm, indicating the presence of the (1120) lattice stripe of graphene [51]. Additionally, carbon quantum dots derived from lignin were fabricated by adjusting the acidic additives containing N and S. The HR-TEM images (Fig. 6c–f) showcased the morphology and lateral dimensions of the carbon quantum dots synthesized under different conditions (BCQDs, C–CQDs, G-CQDs, and Y-CQDs), with average diameters of 2.88, 4.01, 4.56, and 5.05 nm, respectively. The HRTEM images of the four carbon quantum dots showed lattice stripes resembling the graphitic carbon (0 0 2) crystal surface with a lattice distance of 0.32 nm and an excellent resolution [52]. Carbon quantum dots structural effects are usually related to the carbon precursor and the synthesis method. Different preparation approaches and conditions could produce carbon quantum dots with various sizes, shapes, and surface chemistries, affecting their electronic, optical, catalytic, and biological characteristics [71]. 4 Optical properties of L-CQDs 4.1 Ultraviolet absorption Despite carbon quantum dots exhibiting strong ultraviolet absorption, the positions of the ultraviolet absorption peaks may vary based on the method employed for their preparation. Generally, carbon quantum dots show high ultraviolet absorption at 287 nm, which can be linked to the π-π* leaps of the CC bonds and the n-π* leaps of the CO bonds [72]. The L-CQDs prepared using cleaved lignin fragments as carbon sources have shown strong blue or blue-green fluorescence under ultraviolet irradiation at 365 nm, indicating absorption near 230 nm due to n-n* leaps on the aromatic ring. In addition, the absorption at 280 nm suggests that carbon quantum dots undergo π-π*, n-π* and n-n* leaps. However, the fluorescence origin in carbon quantum dots is still a mystery. The present study reports on the optimal excitation wavelengths of distinct cleaved lignin fragments (L-CQDs-1, L-CQDs-2, L-CQDs-3, and L-CQDs-4) prepared, which were found to be 340, 320, 310, and 320 nm, respectively. Interestingly, a “huge red-edge effect” resulting from the relaxation of polar groups such as carboxyl and hydroxyl on the L-CQDs surface in polar solvents such as ethanol and water was observed. The particle size was hypothesized to contribute to the various responses to excitation light [48]. A hydrothermal method was employed to prepare NCQDs with diverse properties using lignin extracted from paper wastewater. The introduction of anhydrous ethylenediamine (EDA) had a noticeable impact on the charring and surface state of NCQD. The samples exhibited peaks at 250–280 nm, corresponding to CC π-π* transitions, and n-π* transition peaks at 320–340 nm for CO and CN in NCQDs [73,74]. The broad peaks of NCQDs at 320–340 nm were found to experience a redshift and, subsequently a blueshift upon the introduction of EDA. The findings showed that NCQDs undergo redshift due to graphite N and blueshift due to pyridine N [75]. Furthermore, the NCQDs suspension exhibited strong blue fluorescence under ultraviolet irradiation (Fig. 6b (inset)), suggesting that the NCQDs had a significant number of surface defects, which caused the electrons to radiate photons [49]. Sulfur-doped carbon quantum dots (SCQDs) were created using a sulfuric acid solution. The SCQDs from lignin exhibited exceptional fluorescence properties and contained abundant sulfur groups. The ultraviolet absorption spectrum of SCQDs exhibited two peaks at 205 and 280 nm, with an excitation wavelength of 320 nm and an emission wavelength of 410 nm, respectively. The emission peaks of SCQD were red-shifted from 405 to 475 nm as the excitation wavelength increased from 300 to 400 nm. In another study, Gan et al. utilized lignin to produce carbon quantum dots via hydrothermal, which exhibited substantial absorption in the ultraviolet and visible regions with absorption bands at 216 and 270 nm, respectively. Carbon quantum dots can effectively capture solar radiation within this spectral range [53]. Carbon quantum dots exhibit strong ultraviolet absorption but cannot absorb visible light, which constitutes the majority of solar energy. This limitation has hindered the utilization of carbon quantum dots in solar energy applications. However, recent studies have shown that introducing heteroatoms through doping can alter the light absorption properties of carbon quantum dots. A significant redshift in AL-CQD ultraviolet–visible absorption spectra was observed in a comparative study between carbon quantum dots and AL-CQDs. The nitrogen atoms introduced resulted in electronic energy level jumps, while the positions of the ultraviolet absorption peaks were modified by the N-doped groups on the AL-CQDs surface, resulting in a polychromatic character and the ability to detect the analyzed light [47]. 4.2 Photoluminescence From a fundamental to an applied perspective, photoluminescence is a fascinating characteristic of carbon quantum dots. This optical phenomenon can be categorized into afterglow and fluorescence. The intrinsic mechanism can be depicted using a Jablonski diagram, where arrows indicate possible electron leaps (Fig. 7 a) [76]. Since the discovery of carbon quantum dots, researchers have hypothesized about their photoluminescence mechanism, excitation-dependent origin, and the internal relationship between their lifetime and structure. It has been observed that small variations in post-processing methods and precursors can lead to synthesized carbon quantum dots exhibiting different optical properties. This suggests that carbon quantum dots represent more complex systems than initially anticipated. As a result, it might not be acceptable to create a single hypothesis by comparing the features of carbon quantum dots as described in various publications. A recent comprehensive review was conducted on the photoluminescence mechanism of carbon quantum dots. It was found that the photoluminescence mechanism of carbon quantum dots is influenced by several factors, including the surface chemical groups/states, surface emission traps/defects, quantum confinement effect, and dopant atoms [77]. These factors determine the carbon quantum dots properties, such as luminescence color, intensity, and lifetime. Carbon quantum dots possess a tunable fluorescence emission and a particularly wide emission spectrum due to their inhomogeneity in chemical composition and size and the uncontrollable nature of the synthesis process. Remarkably, their photoluminescence emission has also been found to be related to the excitation wavelength [43]. Lignin-hybridized carbon quantum dots were created using a one-pot hydrothermal method by varying the molar ratios of ethylenediamine and citric acid. Subsequently, carbon quantum dots were evaluated for their fluorescence properties at excitation wavelengths ranging from 377 to 460 nm. The strongest emission peak observed was red-shifted from 454 to 535 nm, and the maximal emission peaks of carbon quantum dots were observed to be red-shifted to longer wavelengths with a gradual increase in excitation wavelengths along with a gradual decrease in fluorescence intensity. These distinct variations in fluorescence intensities were speculated to be attributed to carbon quantum dots chemical structures, most of which lack graphite lattices. Under high-power ultraviolet radiation, the surrounding solvent strongly affects the fluorescence emission intensity of the surface/molecular states of carbon quantum dots. The fluorescence spectra of L-CQDs exhibit typical excitation wavelength dependence, with all emission spectra showing a decreasing redshift of the maximum emission intensity as the excitation wavelength gradually increases. The tunable emission could be related to the different distribution of emission energy traps on their surface or various sizes of L-CQDs. Additionally, carbon quantum dots demonstrate the highest quantum yield of 43% at 380 nm of ultraviolet radiation [43,79]. The carbon quantum dots (WP-CDs) synthesized from biomass waste, wherein lignin is the primary constituent, exhibit a bright blue fluorescence when subjected to ultraviolet irradiation within the wavelength range of 240–320 nm. It has been found that the luminescence intensity reduces substantially with an increase in the excitation wavelength. This phenomenon can be explained by the decrease in absorption of the WP-CDs. Additionally, the findings suggested that variation in the excitation wavelength affects the emission of WP-CDs, which could be due to the diverse spectral characteristics of the individual emitters. It is noticed that the emitters have distinct dimensions and structural properties that act synergistically to cause the wavelength dependence of the emission [63]. The excitation-dependent behavior of carbon quantum dots has been utilized for multicolor imaging. Gan et al. prepared three different carbon quantum dots, namely O-CDs, G-CDs, and B-CDs, by controlling the precursors and the reaction conditions with lignin acting as the carbon source. It has been observed that with the gradual shift of excitation wavelengths of the prepared O-CDs, G-CDs, and B-CDs towards longer wavelengths, the corresponding photoluminescence emission wavelengths were gradually red-shifted to 602, 515, and 395 nm, which correspond to orange, green, and blue colors, respectively (Fig. 5b). It was concluded that the increase in sp2 conjugation is the critical factor responsible for the red-shifting of the wavelength [60]. Photoluminescence intensity is associated with the acid-base properties of the surrounding environment. It was discovered that the sulfonic acid groups present in the prepared SCQDs facilitated more radiative recombination effects in acidic environments. The photoluminescence intensity of SCQDs was relatively higher in acidic environments, as the sulfonic acid groups were easily deprotonated in such environments. It was further ascribed that SCQDs were more stable in acidic than alkaline environments. Notably, the photoluminescence intensity of SCQDs remained stable within a small range (<5%) when the pH value was between 0 and 5.0. This suggests that SCQDs exhibit remarkable fluorescence properties, making them suitable for acidic solutions with pH values ranging from 0 to 5.0. Interestingly, a red-shifted behavior was observed in the case of small carbon quantum dots (SCQDs), wherein the wavelength of the emission peak increases due to the adjustment of pH from 0 to 13.0. These SCQDs exhibit remarkable fluorescence properties in acidic solutions. Moreover, given that the pH value of tomato paste containing Sudan Red 1 falls in this range, these SCQDs can be a sensor for detecting Sudan Red I in real products [51]. The diverse oxygen-containing functional groups and complex aromatic structure of lignin create a favourable environment for forming surface functionalization and conjugated graphite cores of carbon quantum dots [80]. The ability to create L-CQDs with controllable size, customizable chemical structure, and clear luminescence mechanism is crucial to advance their development for applications in bioimaging, sensing, and other areas [77]. 4.3 Up-conversion fluorescence Up-conversion luminescence can be observed when a material quickly absorbs several photons of longer wavelengths and then emits photons of shorter wavelengths [81]. This unique property allows carbon quantum dots to broaden their absorption edge from the visible to the infrared region, making them more potent at utilizing the solar spectrum. As a result, these materials have promising functions in solar cells, photocatalysis, and photoelectrochemical systems. Similarly, up-conversion fluorescence emission is an optical effect that happens when the emission wavelength of fluorescence is shorter than the excitation wavelength employed. It has tremendous potential in in-vivo imaging, as longer wavelengths of light can eliminate autofluorescence interferences, particularly in the near-infrared region. As a result, this technique is increasingly being used in biomedical research and other fields that require high-resolution imaging. Up-conversion luminescence was first observed when an 800 nm femtosecond pulsed laser was used to excite carbon quantum dots to emit visible light. The finding indicates that the resulting carbon quantum dots have up-conversion properties [82]. Recently, various studies have reported observing up-conversion fluorescence emission from carbon quantum dots prepared using various synthesis methods. For instance, Wu et al. employed a one-pot hydrothermal method to produce photoluminescent N-CQDs from nitrogen-containing silk of silkworms. Carbon quantum dots synthesized exhibit exceptional up-conversion fluorescence emission characteristics in addition to regular down-conversion fluorescence emission. It was discovered that the N-CQDs exhibit up-conversion photoluminescence spectra in the excitation wavelength range of 600–800 nm, which indicates that the up-conversion fluorescence emission may originate from a multiphoton excitation process [83]. Zhao et al. synthesized L-CQDs using lignin cleavage products and assessed their up-conversion fluorescence capabilities. The L-CQDs were analyzed under near-infrared light between 660–760 nm. It was found that the product demonstrated an incredibly high up-conversion fluorescence intensity of 963, possibly due to the abundance of precursor components employed in the synthesis [48]. As a result, the surface defect of L-CQDs was enhanced, facilitating near-infrared absorption and ultimately intensifying upconverted fluorescence. The L-CQDs exhibit bright blue light when exposed to 365 nm ultraviolet and near-infrared light. Additionally, using folic acid (FA) to quench L-CQDs leads to the formation of FA@L-CQDs. The latter compound selectively targets and labels tumor cells via intracellular fluorescence recovery. It has become imperative to have carbon quantum dots possessing up-conversion properties for drug-loading applications in bioimaging. Liu et al. utilized the hydrothermal method to develop nitrogen-phosphorus co-doped carbon quantum dots (N, P-CDs) with a quantum yield of 30% and a mean size of 3.64 nm. These N, P-CDs exhibit fluorescence at 420 nm under excitation wavelengths of 650–850 nm and demonstrate up-conversion properties [78]. They postulated that the fluorescence of the carbon core state in N, P-CDs results from conjugated p-electron orbitals, while the doping effects induced by heteroatoms in carbon quantum dots are likely behind the fluorescence of the surface state (Fig. 7c). On the other hand, the N, P-CDs exhibit up-conversion through heteroatom doping. The introduction of P and N doping provides the extra highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMO-P and HOMO-N) among the band gaps of the carbon quantum dots (Fig. 7d). As a result, this facilitates the absorption of low-energy photons by carbon quantum dots through direct or sequential means, which leads to the up-conversion phenomenon. The researchers have successfully integrated the synthesized N, P-CDs with doxorubicin hydrochloride (DOX) to develop the N, P-CDs-DOX drug delivery system. In order to prevent cell damage due to the exposure to longer wavelengths, N- and P-CDs were detected using 700 nm. It was found that the N, P-CDs-DOX entered the SH-SY5Y cells after incubation for 3 h. The confocal microscopy revealed the co-pairing of DOX and N, P-CDs with red and blue fluorescence colours, respectively (Fig. 7eA3 and B2). Furthermore, the cells showed a purple colour, indicating the successful transportation of DOX into the cells (Fig. 7eC4). This study highlights the possibility of carbon quantum dots in drug-targeted delivery and cellular imaging applications. The up-conversion fluorescence properties of biomass-derived carbon quantum dots have gained increasing interest for their remarkable performance and broad prospects in drug delivery and bioimaging. However, L-CQDs remain underexplored in their up-conversion fluorescence properties and applications. Therefore, it is imperative to uncover the research further and optimise the preparation methods while concurrently improving the quantum yield and luminescence wavelength of lignin derivatives of carbon quantum dots. Additionally, various strategies may be adopted to treat lignin precursors to obtain superior fluorescence performance and up-conversion fluorescence properties. Notably, carbon quantum dots prepared from lignin typically exhibit narrow emission wavelengths, thus improving fluorescence imaging resolution as they emit monochromatic or specific colors. Recent works have revealed that carbon quantum dots exhibit photoluminescence emission in the near-infrared (NIR) spectral region under NIR photoexcitation, further extending their functions in anticancer therapy, bioimaging, drug delivery, and photoacoustic imaging. In short, it is crucial to examine the up-conversion fluorescence characteristics of L-CQDs because of their broader role in bioimaging and drug delivery. 5 L-CQDs for energy storage applications 5.1 Solar cells As the demand for green and efficient energy sources grows, photovoltaic devices have gained widespread popularity for converting light into electricity worldwide [84]. The pressing global challenges presented by the environmental pollution and energy crisis have made it imperative to explore renewable and clean energy sources [85–87]. Carbon quantum dots have shown tremendous potential in multiple applications including photocatalysis, energy storage, and sensing [88] (Fig. 8 a). Solar energy represents one of the most encouraging renewable and clean energy sources offering a free, clean, non-polluting, and limitless resource [89–91]. Hence, using carbon quantum dots as solar cells represents an innovative strategy that offers high efficiency, low environmental impact, and broad environmental protection, with a promising future for development. Carbon quantum dots exhibit a broad range of electronic and photonic properties, which have been widely investigated in terms of their tunable photoluminescence, light collection, remarkable up-conversion photoluminescence, and phototransfer of electrons [92]. Carbon quantum dots have been successfully employed in solar cell development in recent years due to their properties. Fig. 8b elucidates the multifaceted functions of carbon quantum dots and their synergistic photocatalytic reaction mechanism. However, most of the materials related to solar cell production are quite expensive such as various organic reagents and rare earth metals, posing significant economic challenges to enterprises and research institutions [93]. Therefore, to reduce the cost of synthetic photosensitizers and solar cells, researchers have diverted their interest towards biomass-based materials that are environmentally friendly, easily accessible, and cost-effective to prepare the carbon quantum dots for subsequent use in solar cell production. In a recent study, Wang et al. synthesized carbon quantum dots with ultra-high fluorescence properties from all-green Ginkgo biloba and auxiliary materials via a one-step hydrothermal method [94]. The resulting carbon quantum dots were combined with ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) to obtain CQDs/EVA films with high photovoltaic conversion efficiency. Notably, a significant increase in the photovoltaic conversion efficiency of solar cells was observed from 13.19% to 13.65% after coating a 0.050% CQDs/EVA film on the surface of polycrystalline silicon solar cells. This discovery has opened up new opportunities for applying carbon quantum dots in the provinces of photovoltaic, environmental, and energy. Liu et al. revealed that carbon quantum dots can be derived from lotus root incense, followed by doping with sulfur or nitrogen to achieve high fluorescence performance [95]. The study suggests that using carbon quantum dots on the photo absorber of mesoscopic solar cells can improve electron extraction capacity and light harvesting efficiency. The maximum photoconversion efficiencies for two-stage and three-stage photovoltaics were observed to be 0.158% and 0.208%, respectively. Additionally, the researchers fused the carbon quantum dots with N719 dye to improve its electron extraction properties, which resulted in a photosensitive device with an impressive photoconversion efficiency of 9.04%. These findings indicate that biomass carbon quantum dots hold significant potential for high-performance solar cell preparation [96]. In general, conventional luminescent solar concentrators suffer from self-absorption and luminescence loss. Gan et al. have introduced an innovative all-woody luminescent solar concentrator (W-LSC) with directional concentrating ability (Fig. 8c) to overcome these challenges [53]. It has been shown that converting lignin to fluorescent carbon quantum dots and incorporating it into transparent cellulose channels within delignified wood allows for accurate and efficient directional luminescence transmission in W-LSC (Fig. 8d). The synthesized L-CQDs exhibit bright yellow emission (540 nm) and a significant Stokes shift (0.63 eV). L-CQDs possess a high specific surface area and narrow size distribution for enhancing the light absorption capacity and photocurrent generation of solar cells. The L-CQDs surface is rich in oxygen-containing moieties like carboxyl and hydroxyl, which can form an excellent interface with semiconductor materials, leading to efficient charge separation and transmission. Additionally, L-CQDs show a narrow energy bandwidth and high light quantum efficiency, allowing for effective light energy capture and transfer. It is expected that lignin-based carbon quantum dot solar cells will represent a significant development direction in solar cells in the future. This technology is cost-effective, environmentally friendly, and highly efficient, making it a sustainable energy solution for humans. Furthermore, carbon quantum dot solar cell research will drive progress in biomedicine and optoelectronics. As such, L-CQDs hold great potential as a versatile material in the future. L-CQDs have a relatively narrow absorption range of sunlight in ultraviolet and visible light regions. However, their absorption ability in the near-infrared light region is limited, restraining their application in solar cells. Therefore, there is a need for further improvement of their light absorption properties. Additionally, applying L-CQDs in solar cells may be influenced by environmental factors such as temperature, humidity, and oxidation, leading to a decrease in their performance. Thus, further improvement is required to enhance the long-term performance and stability of solar cells. Nevertheless, the existing preparation methods for L-CQDs are immature for achieving large-scale production. In conclusion, L-CQDs possess significant potential for improving photoelectric conversion efficiency, enhancing light scattering properties, and achieving flexible solar cells. As the technology continues to evolve and its associated costs decrease, it is highly anticipated that utilizing L-CQDs in solar cells will prove to be highly promising. 5.2 Lithium-ion batteries Given the global emphasis on promoting clean energy and reducing carbon emissions, there is a growing global demand for renewable energy development [97]. Among the existing energy storage systems, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are widely used in many fields due to their high energy conversion efficiency, stable cycle performance, simple maintenance and adaptable power/energy features [98]. In order to develop rechargeable batteries that are both environmentally friendly and high-performance, efforts have been made to enhance the electrodes and various other components of the battery [99]. Using low-cost and environmentally friendly lignin as a carbon source not only provides a new way for the green synthesis and low-cost preparation of CQDs, but also contributes to the high-value utilization of lignin. Lignin exhibits excellent electroactive redox properties and possesses a variety of functional groups, which provide potential active sites for rechargeable batteries [13]. The ideal characteristics of lignin, such as high thermal stability, good oxidation resistance, and excellent hardness, also confer unique advantages to the components of rechargeable batteries [100,101]. The hydroxyl group is a highly reactive center of lignin carbon quantum dots, which can be modified through methods such as hydroxypropyl and esterification to enhance bonding ability, thermal stability, and high ionic conductivity. Concurrently, the introduction of carbon quantum dots increases the specific surface area and wettability of the electrode material, which in turn enhances the number of active sites on the electrode surface and contributes to the improvement of its electrical conductivity. Moreover, this addition also helps to control the volume expansion of the electrode material during the charge–discharge process [102]. The researchers used a NaCl templating strategy that converts well-defined lignin into porous carbon (LPC) and carbon quantum dots (CQD) [103]. In addition, the abundant pores and channels of LPC can be easily penetrated by molten sulfur to assemble the cathode of lithium-sulfur batteries. In terms of multifunctional biorefining, lignin can easily achieve a novel fusion of CQD and Li-S cathode through a simple NaCl template, which has a particular advantage in promoting lignin valorization. However, there is currently limited research on using lignin carbon quantum dots to produce functional conductive agents with special conductivity, which represents a relatively unexplored and valuable area [104]. Despite recent progress in the development and utilization of L-CQDs, there are still challenges and difficulties in their preparation and application. The presence of unexplored properties in L-CQDs leaves their nanoscale chemical and physical characteristics undefined, which limits their application in energy storage devices. The research on L-CQDs as binders, separators, and electrolytes in LIBs is still very limited. Further work can be carried out to improve the ionic conductivity, mechanical flexibility, and interfacial properties at the electrode/electrolyte interface of L-CQDs, including the chemical or physical modification of L-CQDs and the techniques used for their formation. 5.3 Supercapacitors Supercapacitors (SCs), also known as ultracapacitors, are electrochemical devices that integrate the high power density of batteries with the large capacitance of conventional capacitors [105]. They offer several advantages, including higher power density, high efficiency, high specific capacitance, and a wide operating temperature range. Moreover, supercapacitors are environmentally friendly and capable of rapid charging and discharging within short periods, delivering high power instantaneously. This capability bridges the gap between batteries and traditional capacitors. Due to these advantages, supercapacitors are widely employed in specific applications that demand rapid charge/discharge cycles and long operational lifetimes, rather than long-term energy storage. In the current global context, the application of biomass-derived materials in the fabrication of supercapacitors to enhance the electrochemical performance of energy storage devices and improve energy utilization efficiency holds significant importance and aligns with international trends. Research into biomass-based energy storage devices thus holds profound implications. The unique molecular structure, abundant carbon content, cost-effectiveness, and renewability of lignin have obtained significant attention in electrochemical energy storage systems. Carbon quantum dots (CQDs), as a type of nanocarbon material within the carbon family, are characterized by their low cost, non-toxicity, large surface area, high electrical conductivity, and rich surface functional groups [106]. To further enhance electrochemical kinetics and capacitive performance, the incorporation of CQDs into energy storage systems has become a popular strategy. With their ultrafine particle size and high surface area, CQDs can achieve high carrier mobility and excellent storage properties. Zhou et al. proposed a novel dot-in-sheet assembled heterostructure, which is characterized by all-lignin-derived bifunctional carbon composites (Co-N-C@CDs), comprising porous Co and N co-doped nanosheets and solvent-extracted carbon quantum dots [107]. Through a simple biphasic fractionation, the photophysical properties of lignin-based carbon dots (CDs) were refined into multicolor green and red emission fractions (GCD and RCD). Due to their high graphitic degree and electrical conductivity, the red-emitting RCDs were integrated with layered Co-N-C, which is beneficial for expanding interlayer spacing, facilitating rapid ion intercalation and transfer, and enabling reversible chemical adsorption. These characteristics lead to high-performance capacitive deionization (CDI) and zinc-ion hybrid capacitors (ZIHC). Wei et al. first proposed the preparation of CQD/hydrothermal carbon composites using lignin as the raw material, employing a salt template-assisted hydrothermal method [108]. Using KCl/ZnCl2 as a salt-templating agent provides uniform nucleation sites for carbon quantum dots (CQDs), enabling the regulation of pore structures while ensuring good dispersion of CQDs within the Hydrocarbons. The salt template acts as both a pore filler and a catalyst, inducing monodisperse pore structures and highly crystalline CQDs. The incorporation of highly crystalline CQDs facilitates the establishment of conductive networks within the hierarchical porous carbon framework, which significantly enhances charge and ion transfer rates. The high mesoporosity is also conducive to enhancing ion transport kinetics and capacitance retention. The assembled supercapacitors exhibit excellent energy density, power density, and good cycling stability. This strategy provides a low-cost and environmentally friendly method for constructing hierarchical porous carbons with superior supercapacitor performance, while also achieving the high-value utilization of lignin. Supercapacitors (SCs) and ion batteries are currently recognized as two promising energy storage devices. Batteries provide high energy density, low self-discharge, and high operating voltage, but their power density and cycle life are significantly limited. In contrast, supercapacitors excel in power output, rate capability, and cycling performance. L-CQDs have emerged as a novel type of nanomaterial with significant advantages, and research on their preparation and application has developed rapidly. In the future, they are expected to bring more breakthroughs and transformative progress to the energy storage field. However, the instability of L-CQDs structure and properties during storage or use is one of the challenges that need to be addressed, such as the potential aggregation during storage. Further optimization and investigation of the conductivity and electrochemical stability of L-CQDs are prerequisites for promoting their application in the energy storage field. 6 L-CQDs for photocatalytic applications The efficient utilization of solar energy and the ability to combat environmental pollution have made photocatalytic technology an increasingly favored option [109]. However, some conventional photocatalysts, such as TiO2 and ZnO, face significant efficiency limitations due to insufficient charge separation and transport [110–112]. Moreover, the harmful degradation by-products of these photocatalysts can adversely affect their stability and recyclability [113–115]. Recent studies have shown that carbon quantum dots possess unique photovoltaic properties that can significantly improve photogenerated charge separation in composite photocatalytic systems. Carbon quantum dots can also stabilize other components and enhance photocatalyst visible light response. Doping carbon quantum dots with heteroatomic groups such as metal atoms, S, P, or N has shown promising results in treating wastewater and improving photocatalytic reduction performance. Consequently, carbon quantum dots can be compounded with other photocatalysts to form new materials that can address the defects of some photocatalysts in terms of toxicity and instability, enhance their photocatalytic activity and stability, and make the entire reaction process more efficient and environmentally friendly [49,116,117]. Compared with semiconductor quantum dots and fluorescent organic agents, CQDs possess significant advantages such as better photostability and biocompatibility, low cytotoxicity and easy surface functionalization. Particularly, L-CQDs also offer the benefits of low cost and environmental friendliness, making them highly favored in the field of photocatalysis. When different dopants are used, L-CQDs can emit different fluorescence, which can be applied in photocatalysis for light excitation at multiple wavelengths with its multicolor fluorescence property, thus improving photocatalytic efficiency [118]. Moreover, the conjugated π-structure of CQDs and the surface defects generated by sp2 hybridization endow them with unique upconversion photoluminescence (UCPL) and enhanced photogenerated electron-hole separation ability [119,120]. These characteristics enable CQDs to exhibit excellent photocatalytic activity or the ability to enhance the photocatalytic activity of other catalysts. Therefore, L-CQDs have promising prospects for development in the field of photocatalysis. The applications of CQDs in the field of photocatalysis mainly include photocatalytic redox reactions, degradation of organic and heavy metal pollutants, hydrogen production, and nitrogen fixation [119]. Owing to their unique photovoltaic properties, CQDs can be used not only as electronic mediators, but also as sole photocatalysts in the photocatalytic process, or photosensitizers, spectral converters, and other common multifunctional components of photocatalyst design [121]. For instance, L-CQDs can act as substitutes for noble metal active sites or compounded with semiconductor materials to form heterojunctions thereby enhancing electron transport capacity and boosting photocatalytic performance [122]. The applications of CQDs in photocatalytic treatment of wastewater and hydrogen production are described in detail below. 6.1 Wastewater treatment Rani et al. studied the fabrication of nitrogen-doped carbon quantum dots (NCQDs) as efficient photocatalysts for organic dye degradation. The NCQDs were produced through hydrothermal treatment of urea with lignin from palm empty fruit bunches at 180 °C for 8 h. The study revealed that NCQDs exhibited high stability, high visible-light-induced photocatalytic activity, and excellent photochemical characteristics. Degradation experiments with malachite green and methylene blue demonstrated that NCQDs were more efficient photocatalysts than controls. The results suggest that NCQDs have great potential to become excellent photocatalysts for organic dye degradation [73]. Excessive use of antibiotics in water supply systems has led to significant contamination, making it a major concern in the modern-day world. Recently, photocatalysis has emerged as one of the most viable technologies for antibiotic removal. This is due to its environmental friendliness, cost-effectiveness, and sustainability. However, the efficacy of photocatalysis can be limited by the rapid complexation of photogenerated hole pairs and insufficient sunlight absorption in single-phase bilayered materials. Zhu et al. demonstrated that using nanosheets synthesized from lignin-derived carbon quantum dots with Bi7O9I3 by a simple hydrothermal method improved the photocatalytic performance of carbon quantum dots/Bi7O9I3. Incorporating carbon quantum dots enhanced the separation of electron-hole pairs, light harvesting ability and provided more active substances to improve the photocatalytic performance of the composite. The results indicated that the carbon quantum dots/Bi7O9I3 hybrid material offered remarkable photocatalytic activity, recyclability, and stability. Therefore, it has significant potential for the high-performance treatment of environmentally friendly water pollution using photocatalysis [123]. A set of Z-type carbon quantum dots/BOI/CN composites, stimulated by ultraviolet–visible light, were produced via hydrothermal processes. Fig. 9 b illustrates the manufacturing procedure. Among them, 0.5-carbon quantum dots/BOI/CN exhibit the broadest ultraviolet–visible absorption range, efficient photogenerated carrier separation, and enhanced redox capability. The composite material displays a photoreduction efficiency of Cr(VI) as high as 100% during a 60-min light exposure, indicating its potential for high-efficiency water purification [123]. Additionally, NCQDSs and SCQDs were deposited on the surface of magnetic hydrotalcite using an in-situ growth method to synthesize S-CQDs@Fe3O4@HTC composites. These composites are useful for removing heavy metal ions and organic dyes and practical wastewater treatment. A ball milling process modified the carbon quantum dots/molecular organic frameworks photocatalysts by selecting red phosphorus as the P source, and a nickel metal–organic layer was employed as the two-dimensional molecular organic frameworks carrier to construct the layered composite photocatalyst (Fig. 9c). The material displayed high photodegradation activity for the photodegradation of typical antibiotic TCs [124,125]. 6.2 Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution The global energy crisis has led to an increasing emphasis on alternative fuels. Hydrogen (H2) is emerging as an eco-friendly and efficient solution with significant potential for development. Visible-light-driven photocatalytic hydrogen is one of the most effective methods for hydrogen production, and platinum (Pt) is a highly efficient co-catalyst for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. To ensure maximum Pt utilization, Zhuang et al. have synthesized a novel Pt-NLCDs@CdS nanocomposite by combining NLCDs as a high-performance carrier for Pt atoms with CdS NRs (Fig. 10 a). It was found that the synergistic effect of CdS, NLCDs, and Pt single atoms in Pt-NLCDs@CdS composites facilitates the reaction, transport, and separation of photogenerated charge carriers, resulting in materials with better PHE activity and photostability [126]. A recent study conducted involved the preparation of CdS@CDs/Pt-SAs nanosheets of carbon quantum dots (Fig. 10b). These nanosheets were synthesized through electrochemically anodic oxidation of alcohol in NaOH solution of ethanol and water, utilizing two platinum sheets as counter electrode and anode. The results indicated that the fabrication of carbon quantum dots using Pt-SAs significantly increased surface-active sites, charge separation rate, and solar energy utilization, significantly enhancing photocatalytic water decomposition efficiency. Furthermore, the study revealed that CdS@CDs/Pt-SAs demonstrated a high rate of hydrogen precipitation in photocatalytic hydrogen precipitation even after 20 h of repeated use. Similarly, Pt-NLCDs@CdS maintained a high rate of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution after 60 h of consecutive experiments with photocatalytic water decomposition, indicating excellent photocatalytic activity and photostability. Using lignin as a source of carbon quantum dots for Pt-NLCDs@CdS represents a significant development in photocatalysis. Lignin derived from papermaking waste liquid and logging residues, is rich in an aromatic conjugated structure with abundant carbon content, which allows the formation of highly conductive carbon quantum dots and maximizes the synergistic effect with the Pt single atom [127]. The carbon quantum dots creation via one-step solvothermal carbonization of chitosan was reported, subsequently employed for synthesizing novel photocatalysts of Pt-NCDs to facilitate hydrogen precipitation. These Pt-NCDs were then immobilized onto TiO2 films to obtain Pt-SACs/NCDs/TiO2. The results suggest that the stability and photocatalytic activity of Pt-NCDs/TiO2 were superior to those of Pt-NLCDs@CdS, making it one of the highest records for metal-based co-catalysts. Additionally, Pt-NCDs were immobilized onto mesoporous titanium dioxide films to increase the recyclability of the catalysts. Overall, the preparation process of single-atom catalysts from N-doped carbon quantum dots is simplistic yet effective, leading to optimal Pt utilization. Moreover, this method endows these catalysts with versatility in multiple applications, including electrocatalysis, drug delivery, and multiphase catalysis [128]. The intrinsic configuration of L-CQDs can be tailored using techniques such as chemical modification and doping to achieve optimized photocatalytic performance and stability. These L-CQDs can enhance the efficiency, stability, and recyclability of photocatalysts, thereby rendering the reaction process more efficient and eco-friendlier. This makes them highly promising for application in wastewater treatment and hydrogen evolution. However, the low quantum yield of L-CQDs limits their efficiency in photocatalytic reactions, and their selectivity for substrates is often restricted, making it challenging to achieve effective catalysis of complex multiple substrates. Further research may be necessary to optimize L-CQDs and overcome their limitations to expand their application scope in the photocatalytic field. 7 Conclusions Lignin represents the second-richest natural organic macromolecular material in the world, holding immense potential as a source for energy production, chemical synthesis, and other applications in the face of the ever-growing energy crisis. The extensive aromatic ring structure and carbon components of lignin make it an excellent precursor for carbon quantum dots. This review focuses on the production techniques, features, and functions of carbon quantum dots derived from lignin, emphasizing their potential use in photocatalysis and energy storage. However, certain limitations persist, such as the time-consuming pre-treatment of lignin due to its intricate structure. Additionally, the preparation method for L-CQDs is relatively singular, and future research should explore more innovative preparation methods to optimize lignin-derived quantum dots in terms of morphology, size, optical properties, and other characteristics. The utilization of L-CQDs in solar cell applications is restricted by their absorption spectrum, which mainly targets the ultraviolet and visible regions with limited absorption in the near-infrared region. Additionally, the stability of these dots in solar cells is compromised by environmental factors such as temperature, humidity, and oxidation, leading to a decline in their performance. To overcome these limitations, further research is required to improve their light absorption and stability. Despite these limitations, L-CQDs demonstrate significant potential in enhancing photoelectric conversion efficiency light scattering properties and enabling flexible solar cells. However, their quantum yield in photocatalysis is lower, which constrains their efficacy in photocatalytic reactions. Furthermore, the photocatalytic reactions of L-CQDs have limited substrate selectivity, making it challenging to catalyze complex multiple substrates effectively. Therefore, additional research is necessary to refine their properties and broaden their application scope. Nevertheless, if these limitations can be overcome, L-CQDs are anticipated to have extensive applications in photocatalysis. Although much remains uncertain regarding the electronic and optical characteristics of carbon quantum dots, the outstanding chemical and photochemical stability of carbon quantum dots derived from lignin, coupled with their chemically non-toxic composition, is poised to impact biomedical and bioimaging research significantly. Shortly, it is anticipated that L-CQDs will play an increasing role in photocatalysis and solar cells. coredata.dc:description: Carbon quantum dots are a new type of fluorescent nanomaterials with broad applications in drug delivery, bioimaging, solar cells, and photocatalysis due to their unique biocompatibility, optical properties and easy functionalization. In the meantime, because of its high carbon content, renewable nature, and environmental friendliness, lignin has drawn the attention of researchers as a desirable raw material for creating carbon quantum dots. Here we review the synthesis of carbon quantum dots from lignin, focusing on synthetic methods, properties, and applications in energy, and photocatalysis. Later, we propose some new development prospects from preparation methods, luminescence mechanism research, application, and commercial cost of lignin carbon quantum dots. Finally, based on this, the development prospects of this field are prospected and summarized.
